title: Minuscule 617
text:
Minuscule 617 (in the <a href="Biblical%20manuscript%23Gregory%E2%80%93Aland">Gregory-Aland</a> numbering), O 13 (<a href="Biblical%20manuscript%23Von%20Soden">von Soden</a>), is a <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> <a href="Lower%20case">minuscule</a> <a href="manuscript">manuscript</a> of the <a href="New%20Testament">New Testament</a>, on parchment. <a href="Palaeography">Palaeographically</a> it has been assigned to the 11th century. The manuscript is lacunose. <a href="Constantin%20von%20Tischendorf">Tischendorf</a> labeled it by 140a, 215p, and 74r.
Description.
The codex contains the text of the <a href="New%20Testament">New Testament</a> except <a href="Gospel">Gospel</a>s on 164 parchment leaves (size ), with two large <a href="Lacuna%20%28manuscripts%29">lacunae</a> (Acts 1:8-19:12; Galatians 2:21-1 Timothy 4:10). The lacking texts were supplemented by two hands on paper in the 13th century. The text is written in two columns per page, 31 lines per page.
It contains Prolegomena, , some notes to the Acts, and numerous notes to the Pauline and Catholic epistles.
It has <a href="Euthalian%20Apparatus">Euthalian Apparatus</a>, but incomplete. The text of Epistles is surrounded by a <a href="Catena%20%28Biblical%20commentary%29">catena</a>, the Apocalypse has a commentary.
It contains treatise of <a href="Dorotheus%20of%20Tyre">Pseudo-Dorotheus</a> on the "<a href="Seventy%20disciples">Seventy disciples</a>" and twelve apostles (as codices <a href="Minuscule%2082">82</a>, <a href="Minuscule%2093">93</a>, <a href="Minuscule%20177">177</a>, <a href="Minuscule%20459">459</a>, <a href="Minuscule%20614">614</a>, <a href="Minuscule%20699">699</a>).
The order of books: <a href="Acts%20of%20the%20Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>, <a href="Pauline%20epistles">Pauline epistles</a>, <a href="Catholic%20epistles">Catholic epistles</a>, and <a href="Book%20of%20Revelation">Book of Revelation</a>. <a href="Epistle%20to%20the%20Hebrews">Hebrews</a> is placed after <a href="Epistle%20to%20Philemon">Epistle to Philemon</a>.
Text.
<a href="Kurt%20Aland">Kurt Aland</a> did not place the Greek text of the codex in any <a href="Categories%20of%20New%20Testament%20manuscripts">Category</a>.
History.
The manuscript belonged to the metropolitan of Ephesus Neophytus in 1481. It was bought for the library in "Gallicio" in 1624.
The manuscript was added to the list of New Testament manuscripts by <a href="Johann%20Martin%20Augustin%20Scholz">Johann Martin Augustin Scholz</a>. Gregory saw the manuscript in 1886. The text of the Apocalypse was collated by <a href="Herman%20C.%20Hoskier">Herman C. Hoskier</a>.
Formerly it was labeled by 140a, 215p, and 74r. In 1908 Gregory gave the number 617 to it.
The manuscript currently is housed at the <a href="Biblioteca%20Marciana">Biblioteca Marciana</a> (Gr. Z. 546 (786)), at <a href="Venice">Venice</a>.
